description.narrative:
A new important feature in this new program (phase) for the period 2022-2025 will be going from an operating grant or core support to a programmatic approach. The cooperation between Sida and the UFM Secretariat for the upcoming period will consists of a program focusing on results with strong Results-Based Management (RBM) geared towards improving and presenting the impact of Sida and UFM as development cooperation partners. Measurable and results attributable to this program shall focus on to bring positive changes in the MENA region; focusing on the poor and oppressed. To this effect, the programme will be structured along four main outcomes (program components). In the earlier/original agreement, several UFM Secretariat divisions were in general terms implementing their respective sectoral agendas independently. Under the new agreement, the Secretariat, as an institution, will be working towards achieving a common development impact objective. It will be focused on the convergence of regional inclusive strategies and actions (projects) for sustainable natural resources (focusing on water, blue/green economy), environmental protection, preservation and restoration and resilience against destabilizing impacts of climate change.
The program development impact objective is to support the convergence of regional inclusive strategies and actions for sustainable natural resources (focus on water, blue/green economy); environmental protection, preservation and restoration and resilience against destabilizing impacts of climate change.
Those outcomes will contribute to the social, economic and environmental sustainability of the Mediterranean region in terms of mitigation (protection, preservation and restoration) and adaptation (resilience) of communities and ecosystems to the effects of climate change. In terms of outputs/deliverable, UFM will work within blue economy and water sectors focusing on: i) mobilization and actions (projects) for sustainable solutions; ii) policy adopted and implemented; iii) and public and private investment. UFM capacity building in RBM is not limited to this new program, but it is expected to contribute to UfM aid effectiveness across the board.
